{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3134815,"name":null,"username":"ksquare","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ksquare/{size}/121038_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T12:36:45.024Z","cooked":"

In robotInit, we define some settings that should shown on the Shuffleboard to allow adjustments:

SmartDashboard.setDefaultNumber("Setpoint", 2.5);

In the xxPeriodic(), we then use the current value:

double setpoint = SmartDashboard.getNumber("Setpoint", 0.0);

This works fine when we first deploy to the robot, add the “Setpoint” to a shuffleboard tab, then operate the robot, adjust the setting on the shuffleboard and so on.

But if we simply re-deploy an update to the robot, these types of “Setpoint” created via setDefaultNumber tend to become disconnected on the dashboard. We often need to

  1. Close shuffleboard
  2. Update robot code
  3. Open shuffleboard

If the shuffleboard remains running during robot code updates, “Setpoints” often disconnect on the shuffleboard. The OutlineViewer won’t list them, either.

In previous years, this pattern worked fine. The shuffleboard could remain running, it would keep the potentially adjusted values, so on a robot restart the setDefaultNumber call would somehow recognize that the value had been adjusted in the shuffleboard and continue with that value instead of starting over with 2.5 in the above example.

This new behavior might be related to the NetworkTable 3 vs. 4 updates. Is the SmartDashboard no longer recommended, must one now directly use the NetworkTable 4 API?

I believe this will be fixed in the next wpilib release.

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

[ntcore] Special-case default timestamps

wpilibsuite:main ← PeterJohnson:nt-fix-negative-time
opened 11:59PM - 24 Jan 23 UTC
PeterJohnson
+76 -7

Previously, a setDefault() on the server could override a client doing a real se…t() if the time offset between client and server was negative, resulting in a negative timestamp from the client. This is a not uncommon situation with robot code, as the robot code always starts at time 0, so any clients that set values earlier (in real time) would have negative timestamps. Also improve special casing of 0 in the transmit side to make sure a normal timestamp will never get sent as 0. Fixes #5002. TODO: - [x] Add tests
